Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This course covers a wide range of introductory topics, particularly quantum and molecular orbital theory, organic chemistry, and solid-state chemistry.
A lot of the abstract theory behind chemistry, as well as a good intro to orgo.

I learned about the relationship between chemistry and quantum mechanics, about wave functions and orbitals, about the basics of organic chemistry and mechanisms, about transitions metals, and about solids. I also learned several other things that taught me to think like a chemist.

-Bonding in Solids 
-Quantum Theory and Chemistry
-Orgo
The course content had mostly content that wasn't covered on the AP exam, so it was interesting learning new material like quantum mechanics and organic chemistry.

I learned a lot about molecular orbital theory and how it can be applied to a number of topics in both organic and inorganic chemistry. I also learned how some introductory organic and transition metal chemistry.

Problem solving and "thinking outside the box." Chemistry topics beyond what is normally considered "general chemistry": quantum mechanics, solids and transition metals, molecular orbitals, organic chemistry/reactions/mechanisms/nomenclature, and how these topics all fit together to define the properties of the elements and the substances they comprise.
Knowledge of chemistry.
I developed the ability to make connections between different topics in chemistry in order to gain a deeper understanding of the material.

I think I got a very good understanding of the building blocks of chemistry.  We learned about quantum mechanics, organic chemistry, and solids.  It was a good introductory course for people who have seen a lot of chemistry before.
A pretty good qualitative understanding of chemistry driven by first principles (quantum mechanics).

This class was incredible. I had taken 3 years of chemistry prior to college, including organic chemistry, and honestly left high school hating the subject. This class completely changed my outlook on chemistry and I cant wait to continue taking chem courses in the following semesters. Professor Mayer loves the subject and that really came through in his teaching. I like how the lectures were short but frequent (3/week), and structure of the course (amazing professor, great TAs, and peer tutors) meant that I had a support system that allowed me to seek help. I worked really hard in the class but didnt even do well relative to other people but that doesnt even matter to me! I walked away from the course having learned so much and feeling very content, and cant wait to challenge myself in the coming semesters. Professor Mayer truly made this class.

This class taught me so much about how to learn. Beyond discovering the beauty of chemistry and how the three units connected so well, I got so much better at connecting concepts in my head and learning how to study.

A lot of deeper knowledge of chemistry, especially the physics of chemistry. Also, having an orgo unit felt like a nice introductory sequence as a lot of people will be learning it again in more depth next year.

I learned a lot about abstract chemistry, as well as an introduction to organic, which were hard concepts but  they were pretty cool.

This was my first big lecture class at Yale, so I learned what it takes to be a part of a big lecture class.

A deeper understanding of how different topics in chemistry connect with one another: quantum mechanics, organic chemistry, and inorganic chemistry. I learned how to reason through difficult concepts and look at the big picture of chemistry.

A good introduction to MO theory, organic chemistry, and transition metal chemistry. By the end of the course Prof. Mayer packages everything together nicely. Much more interesting and stinulating than AP chem. I now have a deep appreciation for how powerful quantum mechanics is in describing molecular shape, bonding, and predicting the color of materials.

This class is an excellent introduction to college chemistry, learning not only the basics of general chemistry but how and why everything is the way that it is. I learned how to apply simple scientific understanding to complex questions and think critically about scientific issues.

This course broadened my knowledge of the topics chemistry is involved in. After taking AP Chemistry in high school, I thought chemistry was somewhat math based and that it revolved around reactions. However, after taking this course I can see that there is so much more to chemistry that I still don't know.
I gained an indepth understanding of Chemistry, beyond what was taught in high school. This course really helped me expand what I believed was considered to be Chemistry.
How to study for chemistry, how to take midterms, how to think past just what wed explicitly learned in class
A much more nuanced understanding of gen chem beyond what I learned in high school AP chem.

I gained a better understanding of introductory chemistry, as might be expected. However, it was also a good introduction to university-level science programs and good academic methods. After taking this, I understood what I wanted to do with my life. Dr. Mayer gives wonderful advice, and honestly that was one of the most valuable parts of the class.
I learned about a lot of the theories and concepts in Chemistry, without the numerical aspect.
I learned a lot about the basics of chemistry and a lot of the basic knowledge that is needed to understand how chemical interactions work at a deeper level.

CHEM 163 really strengthened my love of, and awe for, chemistry. Since Professor Mayer focused on a conceptual view of the class, it gave me an understanding of how and why things happened, rather than just memorizing facts. Additionally, Mayer introduces concepts that will show up in later, more advanced chemistry courses, with the mindset that students who continue in chemistry will find those courses easier, and those who don't should still be exposed to the concepts.

This course taught me a more in-depth understanding of chemistry and a better understanding of how things work at the chemical and even quantum level. I also learned to adapt to a professors style of teaching and take effective notes
I learned a lot about quantum mechanics and how it relates to other aspects of chemistry.

I learned how to think and approach chemistry problems like a scientist. I learned a lot about the molecular level and how orbitals work. I also learned about metals and the basics of Organic Chemistry.
I gained a deeper understanding of chemistry and concepts I learned in high school.
Conceptual knowledge of basic organic chemistry, quantum mechanics as they relate to electrons & solid state chemistry.
I learned how to study better, going beyond mere memorization. The class helped me connect ideas and also gain a better scope of theoretical chemistry.

I learned a lot about chemistry, specifically orbitals, organic chemistry, transitional metals, and solids. It gave me a more well-rounded view of chemistry and understanding of how the world works. I developed problem solving skills in chemistry.
Fundamentals of chemistry, making broad connections.

I am not a STEM major, but I still found this class immensely helpful and interesting. It was taught in a way that forced us to be creative in the way we thought about science, and I firmly believe that these skills will prove helpful in my future coursework. I also learned a LOT about chemistry that was far behind my high school curriculum. I thought Id received a thorough chemistry education through the IB program in high school, but I was so pleasantly surprised  by how much incredible knowledge was still out there to discover!
I thought that the class was insightful and engaging. I definitely developed my chemistry skills.
I definitely learned how to think about chemistry more qualitatively. The perspective this class took was very different from my previous high school chemistry classes.

I learned to take concepts/theories and apply them to contexts I wouldn't immediately think to apply them to. I learned chemistry in a way I hadn't in high school, and it was super valuable in that I understand it in deeper way now.

I gained knowledge in general chemistry through a more theoretical perspective than I had before. It has allowed me to truly understand the reasoning behind several mechanisms of chemistry that I would not have realized otherwise.
I developed my understanding of quantum mechanics, organic chemistry, transition metals, and solids.
I got better at using intuition rather than memorizing facts, and even if topics were confusing I got better at going with my gut and understanding core ideas

I learned about quantum mechanics, organic chemistry, and transition metal and solid state chemistry. The class gave me a true conceptual understanding of many of the true reasons behind the facts we learned in AP Chemistry.
The course was divided into three components: quantum mechanics, organic chemistry, and transition metals and solids chemistry. We explored various concepts in each section in-depth.
I learned how quantum chemistry, organic chemistry, and solids structures are all related.

Attained a solid understanding of the quantum mechanics of orbital theory and its application to organic and inorganic chemistry. Mayer did a fantastic job of pushing our experienced class intellectually while also guiding us through new and peculiar topics. I additionally learned how to critically think and work through some of Mayer's nebulous questions on both psets and examinations.

I gained a deeper knowledge of chemistry and learned topics that extended beyond what I learned in AP chemistry. I would say almost every topic we learned I had no previous knowledge of. I learned how to connect topics and ideas between units.
This class taught a lot of material that would serve as good background knowledge to have going into upper-level chemistry courses.

I learned that you need a lot of prior knowledge regarding Quantum Mechanics, Organic Chemistry, and Transitional Metals. This course does not teach general chemistry. Rather, it teaches the three topics mentioned above in a fast and unorganized manner that leaves a student with a scattered understanding of each concept. The questions on the tests do not reflect an individuals comprehension of the general material, but rather an individuals comprehension of very specific facts that are not relevant in the bigger picture of chemistry.
I learned how to think about chemistry more conceptually and thematically (e.g. bigger picture) rather than be boggled down by math questions like in high school chemistry.

I definitely learned how to better apply my knowledge about chemistry to more conceptual and broad problems. Extending my knowledge of chemistry past the plug and chug type problems of high school was interesting and no doubt helped to develop new skills.

There are three units: quantum, organic, and inorganic. This is really nothing like AP chemistry, there is almost no calculation or math in this course (except sometimes for the Sapling). You really get to focus on the conceptual stuff, and learn how to think analytically (like applying equations and what they mean instead of blindly doing plug and chug).
Basic thought processes to effectively navigate scientific questions.
I developed understandings of different part of chemistry that were relatively shallow themselves, but they gave me the tools and preliminary knowledge to dive deeper into each part of chemistry.

I learned the basics of quantum mechanics, organic chem, and transition metals. In high school, I always wondered about the exceptions to the rules of Chemistry my teacher taught me and Chem 163 adequately addressed those concerns.

A much deeper understanding of Chemistry and how everything connects. Attained a brief introduction to the branches of Chem. Much better than Chem 161 if you are looking to learn Chemistry at a deeper level. Memorization is a very small part of this, believe it or not.

CHEM 163 has been one of the most intellectually stimulating academic experiences I have had in my life. The course did not only focus educating the students on fundamental concepts of chemistry, but also it wanted to introduce the students to a conceptual, comprehensive understanding of the workings of science. The course provided me with skills on critical thinking and analysis of information, as it prompted me to utilize the knowledge I had gained in class to solve challenging problems in the problem sets distributed. Furthermore, the class had as its core aim to make students understand the underlying foundations of chemistry and not purely memorize chemical facts and equations. This aspect of the course was, for me, the most interesting one, as I got to answer all those questions that high school chemistry had left unanswered. The course was very well structured, and this structure allowed the students to build on each one of the concepts to acquire a holistic understanding of the foundations of chemistry. The great depth at which the course went when explaining various concepts may have been hard at times, but it certainly contributed to the student's gaining of the a very comprehensive picture of the concepts explained.

I gained an intuition of how to approach the subject of basic general chemistry (the structure of atoms all the way to electrons within wavefunctions, and how those structures affect bonding and structures). I also learned to use some of that chemical intuition (particularly around Molecular Orbital Theory) to approach basic organic chemistry. To predict properties of atomic or molecular bonds, I used a large number of different mental models. I also delved into some of the physical reasons behind those models.

I developed a new, profound perspective of chemistry that very well complemented what I had learned in AP Chem. Instead of training myself to solve a specific type of problem or perform a specific type of calculation through memorization, I was able to think critically and apply the information from lectures/textbook to difficult (and weird) problems that I would have not been able to answer with basic AP Chem knowledge.

In this course, I was exposed to topics not normally covered in gen chem, including organic chemistry, which I found very interesting and engaging. I also learned a lot about the real-world applications and implications of the material we were covering even in basic chemistry, which was very useful and exciting to think about.

Lots and lots of very interesting facts about quantum chemistry, a good solid base summary of organic chemistry, inorganic metallic chemistry, and a bit of  band theory. Really made me think about the intersection of various fields with chemistry, such as especially physics, nanoscience, and biology.

This course was amazing in giving me both an understanding of general chemistry as well as providing very useful information about the complexity of chemistry. It also provided insights on real world examples that were necessary to discus in today's world.

This course really challenged me to synthesize everything I've learned about chemistry thus far. It is not an easy course at all. You do not review chemistry basics; instead, you dive into complex topics that call upon what you already know to understand new concepts.
SO MUCH KNOWLEDGE about how atoms work. I seriously increased my understanding of atomic and molecular level chemistry, and it has really enlightened me.

I loved it, and I have only ever taken one chemistry course in my life (a very basic high school class, 5 years ago). It covers all material, even though it says AP Chem or an equivalent chemistry background is required, a basic knowledge of physics, or even just a strong desire and willingness to learn content is enough to learn everything this course covers.

Strengths: Professor Mayer! 
Weaknesses: The Saplings were a bit of a disconnect from the entire course. Also, Oxtoby was too dense of a read for this course, and if you're trying to learn all the material through the textbook, it'll be a large consumption of your time that might be a waste, anyway, because Oxtoby was often unclear about topics. Also, the lectures for the course often ran out of time, leaving some things unanswered that might be needed for psets or exams, but usually the TFs and Discussion Sections covered the rest.

Strengths-
- Taught me to "think like a chemist" and not just memorize information
- Taught me the science behind much of the common knowledge about chemistry
- Very engaging and interesting
- There is a lot of help available

Weaknesses-
- Sapling problems often did not apply to course material or went into unnecessary detail
- Psets were "flipped" (learned material after doing problem sets)

Strengths:
-Topics are fresh and interesting
-TAs and Peer Tutors 

Weaknesses:
-Lectures could be confusing
-Not enough time was spent on band theory and bonding in solids

Strengths: the peer tutors were very nice and helpful; discussion section with Apala was great; Mayer cared for the students and wrote tests that reflected the material well. Weakness: sometimes lecture was unorganized. A more structured lecture may help the class.

I think the course was good at introducing students to a number of topics that are usually either not covered or are breezed over in high school and introductory chemistry. I think the selection of topics may at times be disjointed, and are as a whole not entirely cohesive (especially the organic chemistry unit in the middle of the course.

The course fits together very well and progresses in a logical manner. The professor puts a great deal of care into the course flow. However, the topics covered in the course are not typical "general chemistry," which could disadvantage pre-med students who will need these topics on the MCAT. A second weakness is that the problem sets sometimes didn't correspond well with the pace of the course and that the Sapling math problems did not match the course (which is conceptual, not mathematical). Lastly, I'm not sure why the lectures are recorded because the recording quality is very low and only captures half the room. This should be improved.

Some exam questions do not reflect one's knowledge of content learned in class but instead reflect one's ability to think (or make cognitive jumps) in a similar manner to the instructor. Some exam questions that are multiple choice should be free response instead because a rational, logical argument can be built for multiple choices, all being consistent (to an extent) with information given in class. While there is a single correct answer to such questions, the questions are poorly written and seem to emphasize that there is only one way of considering a complex problem, when in reality, there are many reasonable ways (only one of which happens to actually occur). Other problems on exams are so remotely related to in-class discussion that they are effectively testing problem solving ability and general knowledge of chemistry and physics, not if the student has learned information in class. The above issues are only relevant to a minority of test problems, but it is certainly a significant issue in the class.

Despite these weaknesses, the course is interesting and informative.
There is a whole host of people there to help you make the grades you want in this class.

I think one strength of this course is that Professor Mayer really cares about if people are understanding the material and how they are doing in the class.  I also think we learned a lot about parts of chemistry that aren't taught as often.
I think one issue was that the course often felt disorganized.  We would sometimes have P-set questions that we hadn't learned about yet in class, and we learned things in a roundabout way a lot of the time.  It was hard to outline and study for the final because it was difficult to know what was important and what was not.  Also, we would often learn the most important part of a section of the course right before the midterm (two days before or the day of), which made it difficult to study.

I think the course could move faster. We didn't cover as much material as I think we could have. Partially this is because Prof. Mayer intentionally moves at a reasonable pace to cover material in-depth, so it's not a bad thing. For my taste, I would have loved to have sped things up a bit.
No improvements. Only small thing I would say is that I wish the curriculum lined up better with 134 lab, and that the review sessions were in the CTL.

The discussion sections are very helpful and valuable, and the professor is amazing. I wish the practice exams were the same difficulty level as the actual one. Also, I wish we had a better understanding of how all the topics connected. The first unit seemed very daunting but by the end I was able to understand it and see how everything came together. The first unit needs the most work in my opinion.

At times, the problem sets were ahead of the lectures which was frustrating. Overall, the lecturing was good and the expectations of our knowledge were pretty reasonable in that lectures would hit main topics multiple times so the emphases were pretty clear. Another strength was Prof Mayers excitement/application of the material. Another weakness was the minutia of some of the physics, especially diving into that as the first unit; it ends up okay but is definitely disarming at first.

Strengths: You meet other people who are interested in taking chemistry, particularly prospective premedical students. You also get connected with great resources like peer tutors and teaching fellows.

Weakness: It is hard to stay engaged in lecture. Furthermore, I feel like I learned more chemistry outside of lecture than inside it.

At times we rushed through topics and I was left to try to learn and understand the material on my own, but Prof. Mayer is a great professor and he really wants us to understand how everything ties together. I thought that the material was fascinating (although conceptually difficult), and the TFs and pper tutors were a massive help.

Although this is an intro course Prof. Mayer really wants his students to understand all of the concepts on a pretty deep level which is great. Everything about the course is conceptual meaning students dont waste time plugging numbers into formulas. That said there were many points in the course where it felt impossible to answer pset questions well because Prof. Mayer had not addressed the topic well enough in lecture. There were points where lectures were our of synch with psets which meant students had to do a lot of extra reading. I also felt that sometimes lectures werent as efficient as they could have been and we only got to the really important concepts of a unit towards the end of the hour when time was running out. Thankfully Things not addressed clearly in lecture were usually addressed in TF section. Be prepared for a good amount of extra reading and visits to peer tutors or office hours. I didnt mind this because i found the material to be really interesting.

This course does a good job of developing a depth of understanding in the areas of chemistry studied, but struggles in stringing these concepts together until the very end of the course. I wish that connections could've been made earlier in the class.

I think this course was designed really well. The only criticism I have is that I didn't really use the oxtoby textbook. I found the Ellis and McMurray chapters that Professor Mayer provided really helpful, but for me personally I found oxtoby too hard to read and follow.

A strength was definitely the discussion sections and peer tutors. Both really helped me solidify concepts learned in class. One weakness was that sometimes the concepts covered on the psets would not have yet been covered in class until after the pset was due.
The only weakness was the lack of practice problems for the final exam.

Professor Mayer expected us to do a lot of the learning outside of class, rather in lectures. There were a lot of aspects of the problem sets that had not been touched upon in class. Peer tutors and TAs were very helpful.

The course is taught extremely well (by Prof. Mayer) and does not present an extreme workload. I think that one weakness of the course is that at times the ideas on the assignment don't mirror what we have discussed in lecture or section, and I think that this could be improved by having someone review the problem sets before they are assigned. Also, the sapling homework, though valuable, seems like it is removed from what is taught in the course.

Professor Mayer is the greatest part of this course. He's super knowledgeable and brings all the information together. The information sheets he made right before each exam were incredibly helpful.

If I could change one thing about the course, I'd make it so that the single class between the 3rd midterm and the final (n- and p-doping) wasn't so prominently featured on the final.
This course does really well when it comes to teaching us the chemistry at a comprehensive level. We definitely gained a better understanding of of how things work chemically.

Strengths: Super engaging, great speaker

Weaknesses: Confusing, super "quirky" exams, psets due on Wednesdays

Professor Mayer has very engaging lectures and is always a great source for help or clarification. He really emphasised how we should be thinking about the topic. TAs and section were also very helpful along with the excellent peer tutors.
The homeworks could match up with the lectures better, but I really enjoyed the way the class was taught.

Strengths: the professor is amazing!! Prof Mayer is super approachable and always seems engaged in his own lectures, which makes listening much easier. 

Weaknesses: Lecture goes through concepts very quickly and without much background. Often I only understood what was going on in lecture after the discussion section met.

Strength: amazing support system from TFs, peer tutors, professor
Weakness: its a very broad class the concepts never sit on you for a long time because you move on so quickly

This course really opened my eyes to the world. It was an intellectual challenge, but I felt that I learned so much. The course covered a bit of everything, and it was a good exposure to the many different aspects of chemistry. The only thing I wish from this course is if it was slightly more organized.

I think my critiques of the course stem largely from my lack of ability as a science student, and not as much from the course itself. My friends in the class who were chemistry majors definitely handled the exam/problem set questions better than me; I found the creative, out-of-the-box nature of questions very challenging, but I wouldnt consider it a weakness of the class.
I think that the class material is interesting. However, I do think that the teaching style is a little sporadic.

I felt that the class was a bit all over the place. I think the order of each unit and how they connected to one another in the end was interesting, but I needed more structure in the class itself. I found both the professor and, as a result, myself a bit scatterbrained and unclear as to what the focus or takeaway from each lesson to be.

Strengths- lots covered, in depth, discussion sections
Weaknesses- a lot of material in a small amount of time

I thought that the peer tutors and TAs were a great asset to the course, allowing me to better understand the information mentioned in class. One weakness is that the pset often covered information that we had not discussed yet in class. I wish that the class and psets were better linked together.

A strength of this course is the amount of help available to students. The peer tutors, TFs, and Mayer are all invested in students learning the material and engaging with it. The peer tutors and TFs are extremely valuable resources and the amount of them and their constant availability is amazing. Also, discussion sections and peer tutoring hours were where I learned the most.

A weakness is the pace and organization of the class. For each midterm, there was something that we learned the day of lecture that was likely to appear that night on the midterm so the peer tutors and TFs had to teach it to us beforehand.

This course it good because it places emphasis on understanding how to apply ideas and not just crunch numbers. It is bad because sometimes the exams do not reflect ideas covered in class, or we are expected to learn lots of material on our own because the lectures never got through all the material.
The material was engaging and taught well. Professor Mayer was a great lecturer and the problem sets he assigned were very helpful preparation for the midterms and final.

I really like how this course was structured; it made sense to start with quantum and proceed to the other components. Professor Mayer ensured that this class made us apply the concepts we learnt. The problem sets and exams really allowed me to challenge myself. I like that there were three midterms; it permitted us to study each section in-depth and then be tested on that material. 
It would have been better if each lecture was better organised.  I think that we learnt many concepts in peer tutor hours and in section before we did in lecture, as many of these concepts were on the problem sets. Additionally, I did not see the necessity of a final exam. If the intention of having the final exam was to wrap up the class and link concepts, in my opinion, an additional problem set would have done this better.

One strengths of the course is the peer tutors. All psets seemed difficult to complete without going to peer tutoring hours. However, at times, I felt that peer tutors were mostly feeding us the answer to the psets and most sessions turned into people asking for help on all the problems. The class itself is somewhat structured, as provided on the syllabus, but I wished there were more bridging of the information we learned. The most difficult part of the semester was the beginning and the end. At the beginning, nobody understood what a particle in a box actually do. At the end, I felt that we rushed through the band structure of conductors, semiconductors, etc. The class assume some chemistry knowledge but I wished better explanations were given to go over those information that we may have forgotten.

The material covered on assignments doesn't always align with what students are exposed to in class. A lot of the material I learned or had to reinforce on my own using the textbook. I find myself at peer tutoring sessions needing clarity on a number of questions. I think making sure students are fully capable of answering what's being asked of them for assignments would be of use.
The problem set questions were pretty helpful in learning the material. For future terms, perhaps more practice exam material would be helpful in giving students an idea of the questions.

I thought the Sapling homework was great and really helped me learn things that I didn't understand. I did not like the p-sets and thought they were not very helpful in helping us practice our knowledge.

Professor Mayer is a good professor, however, the way the course is taught is in such a way that it covers so many branches of chemistry, yet doesn't go that deep into each branch enough to get a really good understating of the material. A strength of this class is that is was not at all quantitative learning, and we did almost no math, but still understood the importance of the equations given to us and how the variables related to one another. I liked that about this class.

Strengths:
- discussion section
- office hours of TAs
Weakness:
- unclear lectures
- unclear lecture slides that often times the teacher would not completely finish
- material on the test that was not explained by the teacher and was somewhat explained by the TA ( there is only so much a TA can do in 1 hour)

The strengths are the exams--they are written with a degree of creativity that I feel fully tests the concepts taught in class. On the other hand, lectures and psets are oftentimes a disorganized and superficial so most of the 'real' learning happens on your own outside of the classroom.

It was a little bit difficult when the problem sets surpassed the lecture materials, which was really the only major weakness of this class. I thought the biggest strength was the material in general, since it was extremely interesting and fun to engage with.

A major strength was the professor who teaches it Professor Mayer. He is really amazing and you can just tell from the examples he pulls on his p-sets and when he talks in class how smart he is and how much experience he has. At the same time, he really understands that there are a lot of first-years taking his class and he really helps us through.
Another major strength is the TA's and peer tutors. I hope next year they are just as amazing, because so many people told me the TA discussion sections were where they did most of the learning. The TA's help you filter out the most important concepts, highlighting them and teaching them in section. The peer tutors were also incredible help with the psets and review sessions. Hands down, they were the most helpful part of the course, I definitely would have done much much worse without them. 
I think a weakness was the Sapling. To me, it felt like more of a nuisance than anything. I didn't feel like they were too related to what was on the psets or exams, and they often asked more math-based questions. I didn't mind it, and most of the time the questions weren't hard or anything, I just didn't really think they were that necessary or that I learned a whole lot doing them.
The article questions feel unnecessary.
Professor Mayer has a wonderful teaching style. It might prepare students better for exams if they had more practice answering cross-conceptual questions.

In high school, I loved chemistry, so I decided to challenge myself by taking this instead of 161. However, going more in depth on this subject than I had in high school made me realize I don't enjoy science as much as I thought I did. The way this course was taught didn't contribute to that; I simply realized that science isn't the field for me. Overall, the course was very well instructed, and there are plenty of resources available for students. However, using these resources (like the peer tutors, office hours, TA's) is very time consuming, and is difficult to make yourself do unless the material is something you're truly passionate about. I'm still giving this course a positive evaluation because I think for certain people, it can be very good.

Professor Mayer set the course in an arch by answering questions posed at the beginning of the class and connecting the three main topics. However, those questions actually confused me. We were not given the answer until the end and by the time the end came, we had forgotten about the question and its connection to the topics.

Strengths: Super cool stuff that we're learning. Peer tutors are a godsend. Mayer is great. You'll love him

Weaknesses: TAs weren't exactly helpful. The exams can be a bit confusing and sometimes go beyond the scope of the class.

The strengths of this course lie mainly on its structure, its philosophy, and its professor. The structure of the course tries to build up on each one of its units in order to help the students formulate a complete understanding of the concepts presented. The fact that the course started with a very comprehensive introduction to the quantum mechanical foundations of chemistry and built upon that in the rest of the units helped me with framing a complete picture of what we were taught. Furthermore, the philosophy of the course, as described on the first question of this evaluation, was intellectually stimulating and targeted the concept of intellectually vitality, something that can also be clearly reflected through the passion of professor Mayer for teaching the course. When I say that professor Mayer was one of the strengths of this course, I sincerely mean it. He managed to take concepts that were very complicated and hard to understand and simply, but very thoroughly cover them in the span of four months. The amount of chemistry that we went over and the depth at which we explored it was amazing for the short period of time that this course lasted. Having said that, the course at times may have felt as too specialized or too ambitious. More specifically, I believe that professor Mayer's intentions to teach chemistry conceptually for first-years may have at times been overwhelming as the concepts that were taught were challenging and difficult to conceptualize. Nonetheless, I believe that the course was amazing, and I can certainly say that it was definitely a very good start for my academic career at Yale.

As I see it, this course has many strengths and few weaknesses. I feel that I learned a lot, and did so in a fairly efficient way. (I learned to expect that some of the seeming misdirection/round-about-ness of the problem sets would, in the end, improve my understanding of the material. In the end, I felt the seemingly strange way the problem sets were written [I know at least a few students had complaints] DID help.) 

It appeared to me that Professor Mayer has really made 163 his own in many ways. As such, most of the commentary on this course also applies to him, and is attached below.

One weakness of the class was that the lectures were taught in a way that assumed that students were already knowledgeable about the topics. It was a little difficult to keep up in class without just blindly copying what was on the board. If students were to read the textbook before class, start the pset super early, or look at the lecture figures before, then it would be easier to keep up. A strength was the TF sections, which were really good at laying the foundation of what was necessary to understand the topics.

The material of the course itself was very interesting and I agreed with Prof. Mayers philosophy of conceptual learning. However, the course felt incoherent a lot of the time because material was not taught in a cohesive mannerfor example, sometimes we wouldnt learn material on the problem sets until a week after that problem set was due. Because he jumped around a lot and things were often out of order, there was an added layer of confusion that was an impediment to my learning.

Excellent professor, well-designed psets that make you think about and help you review the material, Sapling was good for skills practice but isn't the most specific to the course material at times, great support system of TA's and peer tutors.
The lecture style of the professor always kept me interested in what he was talking about and the peer tutors and teaching fellows added to the more basic understanding of the course.
I loved this class! The lectures could feel disconnected at times, but the content was fascinating, the professor was accessible, and the peer tutors were great.
Absolutely! If you are interested in the qualitative aspects of chemistry (the "why") as opposed to just number-crunching, then you should take this class!
Yes, if you really want to have a better understanding of chemistry, and only if you took AP Chemistry and have a really solid understanding of AP Chem (and did well in it).

I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in science. The course is difficult, but it genuinely does teach you to think like a scientist. I found it to be a very difficult but rewarding class. Plus, even if you don't understand the material right away, there is a network of help available which is nice.
Yes. The material was interesting, and I have a much better understanding of chemistry.
Yes, it is more interesting than 161 and is not terribly difficult.

I would mainly recommend this course for those students who want a bit of challenge but who are VERY comfortable with high school chemistry. I would even go so far as to recommend a basic foundation in organic compounds, as the class does move quickly through that portion. Overall, very interesting class with a lot of utility for students who may major in chemistry. Otherwise, I would take a pass and take 161 instead.

I would recommend this to a student who wants to expand upon their existing knowledge of chemistry and learn to view the subject in a different way, as well as to a student who does not mind an intellectual challenge.
Despite areas of this course that need improvement, it is a very information and interesting course.

I would highly recommend this course to students who want to develop a deeper understanding of chemistry- Professor Mayer really stresses the concepts more than crunching numerical problems, which really leaves you with a holistic understanding of the material.
Yes, good course. It was nice to get away from using the calculator in chemistry for once.

I would recommend this course to another student who had taken chemistry in high school and wanted to learn something new.  Even though it was hard to follow at some points, we learned a lot of different things that I think help give a broader understanding of chemistry.
It's quite a nice class! Take it if you want to have a concepts-based chemistry class that complements a good high school chemistry background.

YES. Its challenging, and people will tell you that you can just take 161 and it makes no difference because you end up in the same place, but dont listen to them! I walked out of the class loving the subject, feeling good about how much I had pushed myself and learned, and had made some incredible friends in the process. Professor Mayer makes the class exciting and, while the class is very fast paced and will require a lot of time and effort, is SO WORTH IT. And this is coming from someone who hated chemistry and high school and thought she would never take another chemistry class in her life.

If a student is willing to put in a lot of work outside of class and really wants to learn, then yes, I would recommend this course. My grade probably sucks, but I gained so much and improved a lot throughout the course, and am very grateful for that.

Yes, especially compared to 161, it feels more niche and less rote and boring, even though that at times means the material can be confusing. Its still a good background, especially if youre thinking of completing the chemistry sequence through orgo. Its challenging intellectually, but worth it in the end and everything kind of ends up making more sense than you thought it would.
Yes. I would recommend this course, because although it is hard, it serves as a good way for students to adjust to college level lectures.

Yes, I would recommend this course. Even though the material is difficult to understand conceptually and takes a while to get used to, I felt like this course deepened my understanding and allowed me to appreciate the field chemistry, even if my grade didn't exactly correlate with the time I spent studying for this class.

Yes! If you did well in AP chem and dont want to be bored to tears in 161 take 163. This couse is  interesting and is capable of instilling a passion for chemistry. Just be prepared for a high workload, hard exams, and disorganization at points.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The subject matter is very interesting, and Prof. Mayer does a great job of presenting the information in a way that is exciting and easy to understand.
Yes. I was hesitate to take this course at first but I would definitely recommend it.
Yes, I would recommend this class to someone who has already taken AP a chemistry and who felt confident in that course.
Yes  great professor, challenging course, but rewarding
Yes. This was a great follow up to AP chem. I'm glad I chose this over 161, even though it was difficult.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. I learned a great deal about chemistry, which was the explicit goal of the course. It was also very fun, with interesting material hand-picked by the professor and TFs. The exams were very difficult, but that shouldn't detract from the educational value of the course, assuming that you like chemistry. If you don't like chemistry, this might not be the course for you.
I would recommend this course to a student who is a diehard Chemistry lover and wants to learn about the subject in a different manner, through a different lens.
Yes! It's a wonderful course if you have an interest in chemistry and have already taken chemistry in the past. It's extremely interesting and, though challenging, very rewarding.

Absolutely, if you're willing to put in the time and effort to learn the material. If you just want an easy intro chem course, take 161. But if you place into 163, and you want to know why and how the world works, take it.
I would definitely recommend this course to students who really love chemistry and want to learn it at more in depth way
Yeah, it's pretty fun.
Yes, it introduced me to University level stem and helped me push my boundaries in great ways.
Yes, the professor is great and the concepts are challenging but interesting.
Yes! But only if you enjoy chemistry and have taken AP chem. This is not an intro course for someone who has no background.
Yes, if seeking a challenge. If its just to fulfill requirements, it adds a lot of extra stress.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I am so glad I took this course over Chem 161 even though this course was so difficult because I learned so many new and interesting things about chemistry. This was such an amazing course.
Yes! Mayer is great.

I would absolutely recommend it to STEM majors, as I think it is an excellent approach to general chemistry and gives a unique, worthwhile perspective on science. However, I would NOT recommend it to non-STEM majors. I found it extremely challenging, and not particularly pertinent to what I plan to study in the future. However, I do not regret taking it - it taught me valuable lessons about work ethic and studying habits.
I would recommend this course. Although it was a lot of work, the class was engaging.

I would recommend this class to a student that was truly interested in challenging themselves in chemistry. This course is nothing like AP Chemistry and looks into concepts and ideas that were not explored in high school, and in my opinion, are just more obscure, yet very specific. This is also a very concept-based class and heavy on qualitative analysis, so if you are more interested in the quantitative side of chemistry, I would recommend CHEM 161.
Yes! It's a great introduction to chemistry and the material is fascinating.
Yes I would. Professor Mayer is a great teacher and has taught me to think about chemistry in a different way than I have before.

I would recommend it to someone who enjoys chemistry but feels unready for organic chemistry and wants to learn something new instead of just repeating AP Chemistry (which is essentially what 161 is).

But honestly, I wish that I'd taken 174 (freshman orgo) despite it being a little more difficult because 163 is a little pointless for pre-meds but of course that isn't applicable to everyone.
Not unless they love chem and want a challenge, but because its not really necessary, I wouldnt recommend that anybody take it for fun

Yes. If you want to gain a real understanding of the information taught in AP Chem and normal Gen Chem, take this class. The class is very conceptual but explains the reasons why chemistry works the way it does. The material is generally interesting, and Professor Mayer is an engaging lecturer who truly cares about the class. The workload is very reasonable and manageable, and the problem sets Professor Mayer assigns are the best possible preparation for his midterms and final. Definitely take this class!

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I am not a STEM major and took this course because I enjoy chemistry and wanted to further study what I had learnt in high school. This class enabled me to question the concepts that I knew,  and allowed me to challenge myself further. I think that I really improved my critical thinking skills in this class.

This depends on the student. If there are gaps in your chemistry knowledge, I would take general chemistry. The course itself is structured in that you should have a fair amount of knowledge on chemistry, such as orbitals. Furthermore, psets are much more difficult and more time consuming in CHEM 163. You will struggle if you do not go to peer tutoring. Although I did not have the best grade in the class, I did learn a lot more in-depth information than in high school chemistry.

YES. If you're a student who took AP Chem in high school, but don't have the necessary experience for first year Organic, take this course. I came in super ambitious in my courses and placed into Organic. After sitting the first few courses, you realize that most of the students in that class went to huge STEM schools and have had organic experience in the past. One of the students I sat next to placed into physical chemistry but settled with organic instead. On the flip side, gen chem 161 is challenging but a huge lecture hall with not a lot of interesting topics. Mayer also has an intro to Organic section which is really dope. If you want to challenge yourself in chem but don't want to kill yourself in organic, take this course.

If you previously took chemistry and want to start learning new topics you previously never covered in high school, I would recommend taking this class. If you would rather take a class that reviews the chem topics you learned in high school, don't take this as the course doesn't really review old topics. It is up to you to go back and review things you may have forgotten.
I would recommend this course to another student, but I would advise them to be prepared to put a lot of time and energy towards the course.
I would not recommend taking this course to another student unless they have a solid background in Quantum Mechanics, Organic chemistry, and Transitional metal chemistry.
Yes for folks willing to put in the work to learn about chemistry from a more conceptual rather than mathematical standpoint.

It would definitely depend on how much chemistry they took in high school. I realized my high schools chemistry curriculum was not up to par in terms of some things I was missing at the start of this class, which made it a bit more difficult.

I think taking this class was truly formative for me. It was so helpful to have a well-taught class that was challenging but because it had the right resources available was very very rewarding. I truly feel like I learned how to learn, how to ask questions, how to be a better student, and I come out of this class feeling smarter and with a lot more confidence going forward. I almost took 161 in the beginning because I was scared I couldn't handle it, and I cannot express how grateful I am that I decided on 163. A lot of 161 kids ended up complaining about how they barely attended lecture and taught themselves with the textbook, and I am so glad that everything in 163 was actually engaging and helpful. If you can take this class, you should.
Yes because it is a great class with a great teacher
I would recommend this course to another student if they are genuinely interested in Chemistry because I learned a lot of interesting chemistry concepts and I enjoyed it.

I would only recommend the course for students who are interested in pursuing a chemistry major. In my opinion, the course is difficult and goes very much in depth, which isn't really worth it for students who just need a chemistry class as a pre-requisite for a non-chemistry STEM major. Additionally, it has a high workload, and should be geared towards students who are very passionate about chemistry.

Yes and no. I would not recommend this course to myself because the structure of the course did not help me learn the material. I actually feel behind the students in Chem 161. And I would recommend this course to someone who has had significant exposure to Chemistry in high school .
YES .. if you are looking to expand your view and knowledge in the subject. Definitely not easy though.

I would definitely recommend this course to other students at Yale, especially if they are passionate about chemistry. The course is challenging and it, admittedly, requires a significant and strong background in chemistry from high school. Therefore, I would say that a student that comes into the course should be prepared to not be thoroughly introduced to various concepts that they learned in high school chemistry as they are sometimes taken for granted. That is not to say that professor Mayer kicks of the course without explaining the concepts that he follows. I would say, however, that it is important that one feels comfortable with their chemistry background before taking this course.

Yes  I feel that any student whos already taken a chemistry class should take 163 rather than 161. 

163 is harder  but not too much harder  and comes with huge benefits.
I thought Professor Mayers argument for why to take 163 (and his guiding philosophy for the course) said it best: He was aiming to teach us an intuition of general chemistry, not so much facts and figures that wed soon forget.
I think the deeper levels of explanation and additional material make taking 163 over 161 worth it.

I would definitely recommend this course! Yes, it was difficult and time-consuming, but the new perspective of chemistry that it gave me is invaluable. If you wish to pursue something in science that requires a strong background in chemistry, this is a really good course to take. However, it is necessary that you have a solid chemistry foundation to do well in the course. But it is definitely not necessary that you remember every single detail from AP Chem!

If they are interested in studying chemistry at a deeper level, I would recommend this course because it definitely delivers. However, I would caution that you have to sort through a lot of confusing things on your own which can be stressful and frustrating.
Yes; the content is fascinating and really makes you think about the connections between chemistry and other fields of science.
I would recommend this course to another student even if they are not interested in a STEM focused major. It was very captivating and interesting in class.
Do not take this class unless for your major. Honestly, if you can test into freshman organic chemistry, I would recommend taking that over any general chemistry courses at Yale.
Highly recommend! It really enhanced my understanding of chemistry, which I love. If you have a solid AP chem (or similar) background, I would totally recommend this class.
